t: Proverbs 26
Like*pn snow in summer or rain in harvest, honor*ld is not fitting for a fool.
Like*ln a fluttering sparrow or a darting swallow, an*ld undeserved curse does not come to rest.
A*ln whip for the horse, a bridle for the donkey, and*ld a rod for the backs of fools!
Do*ln not answer a fool according to his folly, or*ld you yourself will be just like him.
Answer*ln a fool according to his folly, or*ld he will be wise in his own eyes.
Sending*ln a message by the hands of a fool is*ld like cutting off one’s feet or drinking poison.
Like*ln the useless legs of one who is lame is*ld a proverb in the mouth of a fool.
Like*ln tying a stone in a sling is*ld the giving of honor to a fool.
Like*ln a thornbush in a drunkard’s hand is*ld a proverb in the mouth of a fool.
Like*ln an archer who wounds at random is*ld one who hires a fool or any passer-by.
As*ln a dog returns to its vomit, so*ld fools repeat their folly.
Do*ln you see a person wise in their own eyes? There*ld is more hope for a fool than for them.
A*pn sluggard says, “There’s a lion in the road, a*ld fierce lion roaming the streets!”
As*ln a door turns on its hinges, so*ld a sluggard turns on his bed.
A*ln sluggard buries his hand in the dish; he*ld is too lazy to bring it back to his mouth.
A*ln sluggard is wiser in his own eyes than*ld seven people who answer discreetly.
Like*pn one who grabs a stray dog by the ears is*ld someone who rushes into a quarrel not their own.
Like*pn a maniac shooting flaming*ld arrows of death
is*ln one who deceives their neighbor and*ld says, “I was only joking!”
Without*pn wood a fire goes out; without*ld a gossip a quarrel dies down.
As*ln charcoal to embers and as wood to fire, so*ld is a quarrelsome person for kindling strife.
The*ln words of a gossip are like choice morsels; they*ld go down to the inmost parts.
Like*pn a coating of silver dross on earthenware are*ld fervent lips with an evil heart.
Enemies*ln disguise themselves with their lips, but*ld in their hearts they harbor deceit.
Though*ln their speech is charming, do not believe them, for*ld seven abominations fill their hearts.
Their*ln malice may be concealed by deception, but*ld their wickedness will be exposed in the assembly.
Whoever*ln digs a pit will fall into it; if*ld someone rolls a stone, it will roll back on them.
A*ln lying tongue hates those it hurts, and*ld a flattering mouth works ruin.
